Federal Court
Phelan, J.
August 17, 2005.
Counsel:
J. Norris Ormston, for the applicants;
Sally Thomas, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Ormston, Bellissimo, Yousan, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicants;
John H. Sims, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Phelan, J.
: Ms. Eun Mee Kim (Applicant) was found not to be a refugee or a person in need of protection by the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) of the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB). This is her judicial review of that decision.
BACKGROUND

[2]
The Applicant, a female citizen of the Republic of Korea, who is joined in her claim by her 9 year old daughter Inn Woo Cho, bases her claim on spousal abuse. She claims that state protection is not available to her.

[3]
The Applicant has a mother and her only sibling living in Canada. As a result, she claims that following their departure to Canada, she became emotionally dependent on Jong Kook Cho. They married in 1995.

[4]
She claims that her husband was verbally and psychologically abusive towards her from the very beginning of their marriage. She was physically assaulted and threatened at various times with either a hammer or with a knife.

[5]
The Applicant said that she told no one about the incidents because of her personal shame and because of the societal stigma attached to such claims. It was only in 2003, when her mother visited her, that the abuse came out in the open. Her mother took charge of the situation, obtained emotional counselling for the Applicant and moved her and her daughter to Canada.

[6]
At no time between 1995 and 2003, despite the physical and psychological abuse, did the Applicant seek state protection.
POINTS IN ISSUE

[7]
The Applicant argues that it was reasonable for her, given her particular situation, not to seek state protection. The Applicant says that the societal values and the shame of accusing a husband of abuse, her emotional dependence on her husband, and, her loneliness in Korea are all factors which make her failure to seek state protection reasonable.

[8]
The Applicant further says that the RPD failed to consider whether state protection was effective in Korea. The Applicant says that the RPD's error was to consider whether organizational structures were in place to the exclusion of considering whether those structures functioned properly.
DETERMINATION

[9]
The burden of establishing that state protection is either non-existent or inadequate rests with the Applicant. There is a presumption in favour of the existence of state protection. (See; Canada (Minister of Employment and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> th)).

[10]
An Applicant's subjective reluctance to engage the state in providing protection is not a sufficient basis to conclude that state protection is not available or effective. In this case, the Applicant never sought any aspect of state protection, even when her mother came to her physical and emotional aid.

[11]
The standard of review on state protection is patent unreasonableness. The RPD took account of the state structure for the protection of abused women; it considered the U.S. DOS reports which referred to some problems in executing on the policies of increased protection for abused women.

[12]
The RPD's decision, read as a whole, is a reasonable and balanced decision. It would be unreasonable to suggest that the RPD must conduct a full review of the effectiveness of state protection in Korea (even if that were possible) in the absence of significant evidence of its ineffectiveness. There is nothing to suggest that Korea's state protection is a sham or an exercise of "form over substance".

[13]
Therefore, despite counsel's persuasive efforts, this Court can find no basis upon which to intervene in this decision.

[14]
This application for judicial review will be dismissed. No question will be certified.
[End of document]

legal_issues: Whether a claimant's subjective reasons for not seeking state protection are sufficient to establish that state protection is unavailable or ineffective.
What is the standard of review applicable to a determination regarding the availability or effectiveness of state protection in a country of origin?
What level of evidence is required to rebut the presumption that state protection exists in a country of origin?
Whether a decision-maker erred in considering the existence of state protection structures without fully evaluating their practical effectiveness.
Whether a failure to seek state protection, despite experiencing abuse, impacts a claim for refugee status or protection.
factual_background: An individual, a citizen of the Republic of Korea, claimed refugee status in Canada with her daughter.
The claim was based on alleged spousal abuse.
The applicant stated she experienced verbal, psychological, and physical abuse during her marriage, beginning shortly after the marriage in 1995.
The applicant reported being threatened with a hammer and a knife.
The applicant did not report the abuse to authorities between 1995 and 2003 due to personal shame and societal stigma.
The applicant's mother and sibling resided in Canada.
Following the departure of her mother and sibling to Canada, the applicant reported becoming emotionally dependent on her husband.
In 2003, the applicant's mother visited, learned of the abuse, and facilitated emotional counselling and relocation of the applicant and her daughter to Canada.
The applicant did not seek state protection from authorities in Korea at any point during the period of alleged abuse.
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) of the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) denied the applicant's claim for refugee status or protection.

Applicants: It was reasonable, given her situation, not to seek state protection due to societal values and shame associated with accusing a husband of abuse.
Her emotional dependence on her husband contributed to her failure to seek state protection.
Her loneliness in Korea was a factor in her failure to seek state protection.
The RPD failed to consider whether state protection was *effective* in Korea, focusing only on the existence of organizational structures.
The RPD erred by considering the presence of structures for protection without considering whether those structures functioned properly.
Respondents: The burden of establishing the non-existence or inadequacy of state protection rests with the Applicant.
The Applicant’s subjective reluctance to seek state protection is not sufficient to conclude that state protection is unavailable or ineffective.
The RPD considered the state structure for the protection of abused women in Korea.
The RPD considered U.S. DOS reports regarding problems in executing policies for protecting abused women.
The RPD’s decision was reasonable and balanced.
It is unreasonable to require the RPD to conduct a full review of the effectiveness of state protection in Korea without significant evidence of ineffectiveness.

court_analysis: The court affirmed the Refugee Protection Division’s (RPD) decision denying the applicant refugee status, finding no basis to intervene. This was based on the applicant’s failure to demonstrate that state protection was unavailable or inadequate in South Korea.
The court explicitly stated the applicant bears the burden of proving the non-existence or inadequacy of state protection, noting a presumption exists *in favour* of its availability.

The court held that the applicant’s subjective reasons for not seeking state protection – shame, emotional dependence, and societal stigma – were insufficient to establish that state protection was not available or effective. The fact that she never sought any state protection, even with her mother’s support, was central to this finding.

The court applied a standard of review of ‘patent unreasonableness’ to the RPD’s assessment of state protection. It found the RPD’s consideration of Korean state structures and reports regarding their implementation (specifically, U.S. DOS reports acknowledging some problems) was reasonable and balanced.

The court rejected the argument that the RPD needed to conduct a comprehensive review of the effectiveness of Korean state protection. It reasoned that such a review was not required in the absence of substantial evidence demonstrating ineffectiveness, and there was no evidence suggesting the system was merely a ‘sham’ or ‘form over substance’.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed.
